titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the New Haven Hospital and Grace-New Haven Community Hospital Collection
New Haven Hospital and Grace-New Haven Community Hospital Collection
titlestmt.author: Finding aid by Toby A. Appel

publicationstmt.publisher: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 02:00

did.unittitle: New Haven Hospital and Grace-New Haven Community Hospital Collection

repository.corpname: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

did.abstract: This collection includes the Dean of the Yale School of Medicine's correspondence and copies of minutes and reports concerning New Haven Hospital, the New Haven Dispensary, and Grace-New Haven Community Hospital; broadsides and brochures concerning these institutions and Yale-New Haven Hospital;miscellaneous materials including historical accounts of the hospital; and newspaper clippings.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Deans' correspondence files in this collection were maintained and donated by Lottie G. Bishop, Executive Secretary in the Dean's Office. Some early broadsides, in particular, the Knight Hospital memoranda, were donated by the Beinecke Library in 1989. Some of the clippings and brochures appear to have been collected by Madeline Stanton, Librarian of the Historical Library. Some pamphlets were found in uncataloged pamphlet boxes that were transferred to the Yale Medical Library from Sterling Memorial Library. Most of these materials had previously been brought together by Madeline Stanton, former Librarian of the Historical Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Yale University or Yale-New Haven Hospital owns copyright for some, but not all, of these materials.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: New Haven Hospital and Grace-New Haven Community Hospital Collection, Historical Library, Cushing/Whitney Medical Library, Yale University

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: New Haven Hospital, originally known as the State Hospital, was organized in 1826 by professors at the Medical Institution of Yale College and other interested citizens. It was the first general hospital in the state and among the earliest general hospitals in the nation. After funds were raised, a building was erected on Cedar Street and opened in 1833. Donors became members of the General Hospital Society of Connecticut. The hospital did not have a direct relationship to the Yale School of Medicine until 1914 when an agreement allowed the hospital to be used for medical instruction and provided for the professors of the medical school to become chairs of the departments of the hospital. As the institution was still largely a charity in the first decades of the twentieth century, only Yale staff had access to patients. So that other physicians could gain clinical experience and follow their patients into the hospital, two other hospitals were founded in New Haven, Grace Hospital in 1889 and the Hospital of Saint Raphael in 1907 (opened 1910). Grace Hospital was founded by homeopaths and eclectics, but had become a community hospital by the 1920s. A plan to merge Grace Hospital with New Haven Hospital was avoided by Grace Hospital's raising enough money to remain independent. In 1944, discussions resumed resulting in a merger under the name Grace-New Haven Community Hospital in mid-1945. This hospital was partly under the control of the Yale School of Medicine but also open to community physicians. Grace-New Haven Community Hospital became Yale-New Haven Hospital in 1965. The New Haven Dispensary, founded independently in 1872, became, by contract in 1879, the clinic for the Yale University School of Medicine. It eventually became the outpatient department of the hospital.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 1 consists of files of the Dean of the Yale School of Medicine (George Blumer, Milton C. Winternitz, Stanhope Bayne Jones, and Francis G. Blake) concerning the New Haven Hospital and its successor, the Grace-New Haven Community Hospital, as well as on the New Haven Dispensary. These files include Executive Committee meetings, medical staff meetings; correspondence; reports on activities, finances, and personnel; and dicussions on the merger of New Haven Hospital and Grace Hospital. Series 2 consists of broadsides, pamphlets, and mailings related to the hospital. These go back to a small sheet in 1826 announcing a meeting to found a hospital. Of special note is a set of forms used by the Hospital from 1926 to 1938. Series 3 includes miscellaneous reports, reminiscences about working in the hospital, and other historical items. Series 4 contains a collection of newspaper clippings related to the hospital.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized in 4 series: 1. Deans' files: correspondence, minutes, and reports. 2. Printed broadsides and brochures. 3. Miscellany. 4. Newspaper clippings. Arrangement within series is roughly chronological.

did.unittitle: Deans' files: correspondence, minutes, and reports

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This material is from the "chron file" maintained by Lottie Genevieve Bishop, who donated it to the Historical Library. Bishop, a graduate of Mt. Holyoke College in 1906, began to work as a secretary at Yale in 1911. She served as Executive Secretary in the Yale School of Medicine from 1928 until her retirement in 1953.

did.unittitle: New Haven Hospital and New Haven Dispensary
Correspondence of George Blumer on the New Haven Dispensary

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: George Blumer was Dean of the Yale School of Medicine from 1910 to 1920. The folder contains correspondence with Yale Secretary George Parmly Day, Yale Treasurer Anson Phelps Stokes, and others, on the staffing and expenditures of the New Haven Dispensary.

did.unittitle: Correspondence of George Blumer on the New Haven Dispensary
Correspondence of Milton Winternitz on the centennial of the General Hospital Society of Connecticut

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Milton C. Winternitz was Dean of the Medical School from 1920 to 1935.

did.unittitle: Correspondence of Milton Winternitz on a proposed merger of New Haven Hospital and Grace Hospital

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Major correspondents include James T. Moran, President of the General Hospital Society of Connecticut, and representatives of the Grace Hospital Society, C.-E. A. Winslow, Professor of Public Health, and John L. Rice, Health Officer of New Haven. See Box 5, folders 1 and 2.

did.unittitle: Correspondence of Milton Winternitz on a proposed merger of New Haven Hospital and Grace Hospital

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Included are typescripts, "Report re New Haven Hospital and Dispensary," March 12, 1938; and Michael M. Davis with the assistance of Leonard Greenburg and Louise W. Farnam, "Report on Medical Institutions in New Haven," March 1928.

did.unittitle: Correspondence of Milton Winternitz on a porposed merger of New Haven Hospital and Grace Hospital

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Discussion of a merger ended when Grace Hospital managed to raise enough funds to avoid merger. The issue reappeared in 1944-1945. See related newspaper clippings in Box 5, folder 1.

did.unittitle: "The Relation of New Haven Hospital to the General Hospital Situation in New Haven"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copy of a typescript written from the perspective of New Haven Hospital. No author is attributed.

did.unittitle: Reports and statistics of the New Haven Dispensary
Proposals by Yale to the Josiah Macy Foundation to study the economics of hospital care
H. Gilbert Francke, "Survey of the Personnel Problems of the New Haven Hospital"
Reports of Camp Happyland/William Wirt Winchester Hospital

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The William Wirt Winchester Hospital was the tuberculosis hospital of New Haven Hospital. It was located on the grounds of the current VA Hospital in West Haven. Camp Happyland was a summer camp on the grounds of the William Wirt Hospital for the prevention of tuberculosis among children (a "preventorium"). See also Box 5, folder 4.

did.unittitle: John Schoolcraft, "New Haven Hospital"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: With letter from Schoolcraft to Stanhope Bayne-Jones, dated July 13, 1938. Bayne-Jones served as Dean of the Yale School of Medicine from 1935 to 1940.

did.unittitle: "The New Haven Dispensary, Founded 1872: A Statement of its History, Services, and Needs"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Carbon copy of a typescript.

did.unittitle: New Haven Hospital, "Blood Banking Procedures"
"New Haven Hospital and New Haven Dispensary: Next Steps in Development"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sent to Stanhope Bayne-Jones by John Schoolcraft, May 8, 1940.

did.unittitle: Irma Biehusen, "A Study of the Health Service for Personnel of the New Haven Hospital"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sent to Stanhope Bayne-Jones by James A. Hamilton, Director of New Haven Hospital, May 9, 1940. Biehusen, who collaborated with the hospital administration on this report, used it for her dissertation for her Yale Masters of Public Health.

did.unittitle: "New Haven Hospital Defense Program"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mimeograph emergency plans for civilian defense during the war.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Francis G. Blake served as Dean of the Yale School of Medicine from 1941 to 1947.

Notice of a meeting to discuss founding a "General State Hospital"

scopecontent.p: Print signature of William Leffingwell, President of the Board of Directors. The meeting was to be held on April 9 [1826].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copy of the handwritten charter made by the Secretary of State's office for John Schoolcraft and given to Lottie G. Bishop in 1940

did.unittitle: Fundraising broadsides

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gift of the Beinecke Library, 1989.

did.unittitle: Membership certificate for the General Hospital Society of Connecticut

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Made out to John Skinner who paid twenty dollars to become a member for life.

did.unittitle: Fundraising circular

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Print signature by Jonathan Knight.

did.unittitle: Knight U.S.A. General Hospital, "General Orders"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: During the Civil War, New Haven Hospital was converted to military use and was known as Knight Hospital. The folder contains one-page printed memoranda from Pliny A. Jewett, "Surgeon U. S. V., Comd'g Hospital."

did.unittitle: Fundraising broadside

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The General Assembly granted the Hospital Society of Connecticut $20,000 on condition that a like amount could be raised by private donations. Printed signatures of William W. Boardman, Yale Medical Dean Charles A. Lindsley, and Horace Day.

did.unittitle: Hospital formularies
Appeal for funds and donation form
Flyers for Hospital Sunday

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: All but the first two flyers were transferred by the Beinecke Library. Hospital Sunday was an annual fundraiser for the Hospital.

did.unittitle: Circular to raise funds for laundry machinery

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This would replace hand washing and save money.

unittitle.emph: The Farnam Ward of New Haven Hospital

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [New Haven, n.d] Another copy of this brochure has been individually cataloged.

did.unittitle: Charity Ball for the benefit of New Haven Hospital

unittitle.emph: Catalogue of Books in the New Haven Hospital Library

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These appear to be books for patients and are listed under such categories as Adventure and Travel, Biography, Fiction, etc.

did.unittitle: Fundraising broadside

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: From the Prudential Committee consisting of Charles Ray Palmer, Charles E. Graves, and William G. Daggettt.

did.unittitle: "By-Laws" and "Rules" of New Haven Hospital
Brochures and miscellany

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes brochures on the new buildings of the New Haven Hospital including the Private Pavilion, Brady Memorial Laboratory, Lauder Hall, and the Farnam Memorial Building; and a Yale University News statement announcing that the General Education Board of the Rockerfeller Foundation had given two million dollars for a new laboratory and for the Clinic building. There is also a pamphlet, "Information Relative to Interneship" (1927) with notes on revision for a later year.

did.unittitle: Raleigh Fitkin Memorial Building brochures and memorabilia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes copy of the typescript "'Minutes of the Meeting of the Committee on the dedication of the Raleigh Fitkin Memorial," December 20, 1929.

did.unittitle: Camp Happyland/ William Wirth Winchester Hospital brochures

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The William Wirt Winchester Hospital, part of New Haven Hospital, was founded in 1911 at the site of what is now the VA Hospital in West Haven. It treated patients with tuberculosis. Camp Happyland, a summer camp for children on the hospital grounds, provided outdoor activities for children in an effort to prevent tuberculosis.

did.unittitle: Brochures and miscellany

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes "Information Relative to Internship," 1933.

did.unittitle: New Haven Hospital forms

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A wide variety of hospital forms for admitting and discharging patients, requesting tests, recording patient care, reporting deaths, ordering supplies, regulations for visitors, applications for interneship, etc.

did.unittitle: New Haven Hospital forms
New Haven Hospital pamphlet series

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series of eleven illustrated public information pamphlets on New Haven Hospital including pamphlets on infantile paralysis, x-ray facilities, and Camp Happyland.

did.unittitle: "Out Patient Department of the New Haven Hospital (New Haven Dispensary), Schedule of Clinics"
Brochures and miscellany
Brochures and miscellany

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes a Resident Staff Manualfor 1949.

did.unittitle: Grace-New Haven Commmunity Hospital brochures and miscellany
Grace-New Haven Community Hospital and Yale-New Haven Medical Center brochures and miscellany

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Yale-New Haven Medical Center was incorporated in 1955. Folder includes material on the dedication of the Hunter Radiation Therapy Building, 1958.

did.unittitle: Grace-New Haven Community Hospital and Yale-New Haven Medical Center brochures and miscellany
Yale News release on the formation of Yale-New Haven Hospital
Yale-New Haven Hospital brochures and miscellany
Internship and residency brochures
Yale-New Haven Hospital sesquicentennial celebration
Miscellaneous materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes non-published material from sources other than the Dean's files.

did.unittitle: Postmortem examination at New Haven Hospital and possibly related materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Postmortem examination of John Barber, a black man, by Moses C. White at request of the coroner. This case appeared to have led to criticism in the press and a call for an investigation. These materials were donated by Dr. Frederick N. Sperry from the library of Dr. Henry L. Swain, 1944.

did.unittitle: Lybrand, Ross Bros. & Montgomery, "New Haven Hospital: Report on Survey of Certain Accounting Methods"
Painted drawing: "New Haven Hospital, 37,000 Days of Free Care in 1933"
"Hospitals and Medicine"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A mimeograph history of New Haven Hospital by the Community Chest and the Council of Social Agencies, New Haven. The folder also contains a typed extract on the Hospital from a published article on the history of the Connecticut Medical Society in 1892.

did.unittitle: Henry R. Viets, National Association for Infantile Paralysis, "Notes on the New Haven Epidemic, 1943"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Polio patients were treated at the New Haven Hospital. Sent to the Historical Library at the request of John F. Fulton.

did.unittitle: "I Remember When" - personal reminisences of New Haven Hospital

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These were assembled by J. H. Wallace and included two deans of the Yale School of Nursing, and various employees of the hospital. There is also a detailed timeline of the history of New Haven Hospital.

did.unittitle: John F. Fulton, "Notes on the History of Grace-New Haven Community Hospital and the General Hospital Society of Connecticut"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Talk in the Fitkin Amphitheater to the Board of Directors of Grace-New Haven Community Hospital.

Lists of officers, directors, and advisory boards, 1959-1968

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Requested by Lottie G. Bishop, office of the Secretary, Yale University, and supplied by Richard H. Judd, Assistant Director of Yale-New Haven Hospital.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning unionizing Grace-New Haven Community Hospital employees.
